heading: third voice rips holes in web
subheading: web utility third voice not only lets users open their minds through lively debate -- it can also open their browsers to security risks. by chris oakes.
author: chris oakes
text: third voice, a web annotation utility, is more powerful than its authors intended -- in addition to providing freedom of expression, it can call up users' data and be used to generate fake web pages. software programmers in the us and europe have discovered security holes that turn third voice into a cracking tool.the software works as a browser companion, similar to alexa internet. when installed on a personal computer, the user can publicly annotate the face of any web page. comments and ensuing responses are posted in the form of electronic sticky notes. other visitors to the site use their own third voice software to read the comments attached to a site.internet users, law professors, and critics have reacted in different ways to the software's web-page annotation capabilities, calling it everything from the ultimate free speech communications tool to the equivalent of a graffiti spray can.vulnerabilities were first discovered by michigan-based programmer jeremy bowers, who found that the software hole allowed users to post not just text but programming code in third voice notes. once executed on other third voice users' computers, the code, if maliciously designed, could perform a variety of compromising tasks.bowers said he could use the security glitch, for example, to cause faked versions of a web page to appear to third voice users. while the actual page wasn't changed, a page generated by the javascript made it appear as if it had been, he said. a third voice user interacting with a fake page could unwittingly transmit sensitive user data such as an id and passwords for a particular web site.bowers was also able to enter javascript into messages despite third voice's blocking system. he did so by using codes that the service's filters failed to detect.
